title: Jazz musician canceled for supporting 50 remaining hostages in Gaza at festival: 'I'm not a politician'
summary: Berlin swing musician David Hermlin said he was canceled from European jazz festivals after asking questions to pro-Palestinian activists and wearing a Gaza hostage pin.
story: Berlin swing musician David Hermlin tells Fox News Digital he was excluded from festivals after asking two questions and wearing a yellow pin in support of hostages still held in Gaza.

Berlin swing musician David Hermlin says he is facing cancellation after being excluded from some of Europe’s leading jazz festivals and accused of intimidation at a meeting organized by a pro-Palestinian group. The 25-year-old told Fox News Digital that his only actions were asking two questions and wearing a yellow pin in solidarity with hostages still held in Gaza."I didn’t harass or intimidate anyone. I merely asked two questions I thought were legitimate," Hermlin said.

Known on social media as "Daveetheewave," Hermlin has built a reputation not just for his music but for his image. He dresses in authentic 1930s fashion, complete with slicked-back hair, vintage microphone, and a charcoal gray suit that looks plucked from a Fred Astaire film.BBC DEEMED UK PUNK-RAP DUO 'HIGH RISK' BEFORE CONTROVERSIAL ANTI-ISRAEL PERFORMANCE
08 April 2025, Berlin: David Hermlin attends the "B.Z.-Kulturpreis" award ceremony. (Annette Riedl/picture alliance via Getty Images)

The look fits the sound. He sings classics like "Let’s Fall in Love" backed by his own big band, The Swing Dance Orchestra, that re-creates the golden era of swing down to the last detail. His yellow ribbon pin, worn neatly on the lapel of that tailored suit, stood out at this year’s festival and became a flashpoint in the controversy.

Hermlin’s experience raises questions about free speech in the entertainment world. He frames his case as part of a broader historical pattern of exclusion."What kind of a world is this now that before I can play at a festival, I have to make a political statement? It’s a music festival, not a political festival," he said.ANTI-ISRAEL BAND PLAYS VICTIM AFTER BEING HAMMERED FOR SAYING ‘DEATH TO THE IDF’ DURING MUSIC FESTIVAL
David Hermlin, center in red jacket, plays drums surrounded by his big band orchestra. (Uwe Hauth)

The Herräng Dance Camp in Sweden is considered one of the world’s most recognized swing festivals. At this year’s gathering, a group called Jazz with Palestine held an open meeting. Hermlin was performing as a drummer with another ensemble, not his own orchestra. He later learned that organizers not only excluded him from that group’s jam sessions but also made it clear they would not consider booking his personal projects, like The Swing Dance Orchestra."I went with the sole intention to just listen to their concerns and if possible have a dialogue," Hermlin explained.

At the Jazz with Palestine meeting, Hermlin asked two questions. He wanted to know where monetary donations would be directed, and what the lyrics of the Arabic song used for choreography meant. The exchange later prompted complaints about his "intimidating presence.""The first question was, if I want to donate some money, where are the donations going?" Hermlin recalled. "The second was, what’s the meaning of the Arabic song? They said they didn’t know. I asked, wouldn’t it be nice to know before filming a choreography?"STATE DEPARTMENT PULLS VISAS FOR BRITISH BAND BOB VYLAN, FOLLOWING ‘DEATH TO THE IDF’ CHANTS AT GLASTONBURY
Andrej Hermlin and David Hermlin during the Askania Award 2023 at Berlin Capital Club on February 14, 2023 in Berlin, Germany. (Tristar Media/Getty Images)
He said he was stunned when a board member told him some attendees were uncomfortable.

Hermlin also faced criticism for wearing the small yellow lapel pin, which symbolizes solidarity with the 50 hostages still held by Hamas. Festivalgoers suggested the pin was inflammatory or political propaganda. Hermlin rejects that characterization."People pointed at my yellow pin and said, maybe people are aggressive because of your pin. I asked them, do you know what it means? They said no," he said. "This pin is about the hostages. It’s not about the IDF or the government. It’s about empathy."

After Herräng, Hermlin said other festivals began dropping him from their lineups while keeping his band. "I’m the only one being excluded. Not the band, just me," he said. "A festival told me, don’t take it personally, you’ll get a cancellation fee. But how is that not personal?"

09 October 2021, Berlin: Andrej Hermlin (l-r) with daughter Rachel Hermlin and brother David Hermlin come to "80 Years Eckart Witzigmann - Berlin Says Thank You" at the KPM Königliche Porzellan-Manufaktur. (Gerald Matzka/picture alliance via Getty Images)

Fox News Digital reached out to Jazz with Palestine for comment but did not receive a response. On its website and social media, the group describes itself as a movement of jazz and swing dancers across Europe who use music, dance, and political action to stand with the Palestinian people. Its mission statement says the group raises awareness and funds and that jazz is rooted in the "fight against racial and colonial oppression." The group has recently promoted fundraising efforts for humanitarian groups in Gaza and announced plans for social dance events and educational forums.

Hermlin says the treatment reminds him of both the McCarthy era and his own family’s history in Berlin during the 1930s. He also points to the swing world’s history of exclusion. "It reminds me of the McCarthy era, when artists were pressed to declare if they were communists. If you said yes, you were boycotted," he said. "They did this in front of photos of Norma Miller, Frankie Manning, and the Nicholas Brothers, artists excluded in the 1930s. How ironic is that?"

He also cites Benny Goodman, the Jewish clarinetist who became the "King of Swing" and defied segregation by hiring Black musicians such as Teddy Wilson, Lionel Hampton, and Charlie Christian. "As Benny Goodman showed in the 1930s, swing is about inclusion. That’s its very soul," Hermlin said.

Despite the fallout, Hermlin vows to keep playing. "I had no choice but to speak up. Music should unite and not divide," he said.CLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP"I never wanted to be dragged into politics. I’m a swing musician, not a politician — my instrument is the drums, not a political statement." "My way of fighting back is to keep swinging. That’s what I’ll do. I always end my concerts by saying, don’t forget, keep swinging. And I mean it."
Jasmine Baehr is a Breaking News Writer for Fox News Digital, where she covers politics, the military, faith and culture.

title: Judge temporarily blocks Trump's firing of Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook
summary: A federal judge on Tuesday granted a temporary restraining order blocking President Donald Trump’s firing of Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook for now
story: A federal judge on Tuesday granted a temporary restraining order blocking President Donald Trump’s firing of Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook for now.
The ruling means Cook will remain on the board of the central bank until her case is heard at length. She is allowed to continue carrying out her work during that time.

In granting the order, U.S. District Judge Jia Cobb said that "the Court will enter an injunction directing [Fed Chair Jerome] Powell and the Board of Governors to allow Cook to continue to operate as a member of the Board for the pendency of this litigation."

"The public interest in Federal Reserve independence weighs in favor of Cook’s reinstatement," Cobb wrote. "That independence is critical in helping the nation’s 'banking system to promote stability.'"

Lawyers for Cook argued in federal court in Washington that Trump’s attempt to fire her for “mortgage fraud” was illegal and lacked “cause,” which is the only reason a Fed governor can be removed. “Cause” is commonly understood to be some kind of wrongdoing.
The ruling means that Cook could participate in the Fed's highly anticipated two-day meeting that starts Sept. 16, when the central bank is likely to decide to lower interest rates.
Trump moved to fire Cook in late August, citing allegations of mortgage fraud brought by one of his political appointees. Cook has not been charged with any crime.
"Governor Cook did not ever commit mortgage fraud," Cook's lawyers wrote in a filing last week.

A White House spokesman argued in a statement Tuesday night that Trump "lawfully removed Lisa Cook for cause due to credible allegations of mortgage fraud from her highly sensitive position overseeing financial institutions on the Federal Reserve Board of Governors."
"This ruling will not be the last say on the matter, and the Trump Administration will continue to work to restore accountability and confidence in the Fed," spokesman Kush Desai said.
The Federal Reserve declined to comment on the order. It previously said in a statement that it would "abide by any court decision."

Abbe Lowell, who is representing Cook, said in a statement: “Today’s ruling recognizes and reaffirms the importance of safeguarding the independence of the Federal Reserve from illegal political interference. Allowing the President to unlawfully remove Governor Cook on unsubstantiated and vague allegations would endanger the stability of our financial system and undermine the rule of law. Governor Cook will continue to carry out her sworn duties as a Senate-confirmed Board Governor."

Cook is the first Black woman to serve as a governor on the board of the Fed in its more than 110-year history. Before she joined the Fed, she was a professor of economics and international relations at Michigan State University.

title: In 'The History of Sound,' Paul Mescal and Josh O'Connor anchor a tender WWI-era romance
summary: “What if your first love is your greatest love — and your last love?” That is the question at the heart of “The History of Sound,” the new historical romantic drama starring Paul Mescal and Josh O’Connor.
story: “What if your first love is your greatest love — and your last love?” That is the question at the heart of “The History of Sound,” the new historical romantic drama starring Paul Mescal and Josh O’Connor, which premieres Friday in theaters.

Directed by Oliver Hermanus and adapted by writer Ben Shattuck from his own short story of the same name, the film explores the impact of a fleeting romance between Lionel (Mescal) and David (O’Connor), two Boston Conservatory music students who meet at a piano bar in 1917 — where Lionel overhears David singing a song from his youth — and quickly fall for each other. Several years later, after serving in World War I, David asks Lionel to join him on an impromptu trip through the backwoods of Maine to collect traditional folk songs in order to preserve them for future generations.

“What I find so interesting about the film is it’s not that trope of, man walks into a bar, looks across the bar, sees somebody who he fancies, and they fall in love. It’s the opposite. You see the back of David’s head, and you see the back of Lionel’s head, and the script explained to us that these are two people who met through sound,” Mescal told NBC News in a joint interview with O’Connor. “It’s not one of physical chemistry, initially; it’s one of intellectual and artistic chemistry.”
O’Connor described the characters’ relationship as an “outward-looking” romance and said he was drawn to the way “their entire relationship is seeking other stuff to add to it.”

“The adventure that they go on is all about inviting other people into their world,” he said. “It’s a very selfless romance in that sense, so I think that was something that I hadn’t seen in a film before, and that felt really a different way of telling a love story.”

Even decades after they part ways, Lionel is constantly drawn back to his memories of his brief time with David. For Hermanus — whose past films “Beauty” (2011) and “Moffie” (2019) have examined the brutal, “political side of queerness” in his native South Africa — “The History of Sound” represented an opportunity to tell a sweeping gay love story that he would want to watch.

“Life should be full of longing and remembrance,” he said. “There should be a dramatic element to life where things don’t always work out the way that you expect, but there’s this cherishing of the things that you have, the things that you experience. I think that’s a very realistic or very poetic way of seeing one’s life.”

The filmmaker was particularly insistent about crafting a central romance that runs counter to depictions of same-sex relationships during that era, which were often characterized by danger and secrecy. Lionel and David never explicitly label their relationship, and their romance exists in somewhat of a bubble.

“The greater political act of making a film like this is to not give the politics any oxygen,” Hermanus said. “The great liberation here is that the film is itself, and the characters are themselves without explanation.”

Mescal and O’Connor first met early during the Covid-19 pandemic, when their mutual agent offered to set them up on a Zoom call. Mescal was just coming off the success of “Normal People,” while O’Connor was in the middle of a two-season run as Prince Charles on “The Crown.” The actors immediately bonded over a similar taste in actors, films and directors, and they subsequently signed on to “The History of Sound” separately. The film faced numerous delays — first with financing, and then with the pandemic and dual Hollywood strikes. But even as their profiles rose, both actors remained committed to making the film.

“We were weirdly lucky that the film took as long as it did to make, because it didn’t mean that we had to do a crash course in friendship in the weeks leading up to shooting. It was just something that naturally evolved over five years,” Mescal said. “We entered it at the perfect point where we really knew each other and liked each other, and then I think we fell in love with each other making it.”
Because the film took so long to finance and make, Hermanus said, he “was able to observe the kind of closeness” his leading men had.
“What they really have as Paul and Josh is a kind of very brotherly love, which is about pranks and foolery, and that was kind of the energy we had on set,” he said.

That playfulness was a way for the actors to offset the quiet grief and heartache of the story. In the final act of the film, Lionel discovers that the “very passionate music-loving person” he fell in love with “has been dimmed by the trauma of war,” Hermanus said. “That song-collecting trip does become the blooming of their relationship, but it also becomes the foreshadowing, because by the time they meet up on that trip, they’ve changed.”

“The way David sees the world is so pure and so joyful, and he’s like the purest optimist. Ultimately, this whole adventure is about and for his love of music; it’s also for his love of Lionel. It’s him making space for them to be able to experience something that they love together in the most pure and exciting way,” O’Connor added. “The sadness that goes alongside that is that we discover that behind that kind of wide-eyed optimism is a sort of intrinsic sadness, and that’s the pain of the movie. Seeing that through Lionel’s eyes retrospectively, that’s what’s so powerful.”

Neither Mescal nor O’Connor is a stranger to telling bittersweet gay love stories: O’Connor broke out in 2017’s “God’s Own Country,” while Mescal cemented his status as one of Hollywood’s rising leading men in 2023’s “All of Us Strangers.” Both actors, who have admitted to having mixed feelings about the subject of whether straight actors should play queer characters, say the conversation is an ever-evolving one.

“It’s a conversation that’s definitely evolved since I’ve been in drama school to now, and I’m very grateful for it, because I would never want to be just only able to play things that feel close to me, and it’s not that sexuality is the defining factor. In fact, I feel closer to a lot of the characters that are gay than the ones that are straight. It’s not to do with that,” Mescal said. “I don’t think it’s exclusive to the gay men that I’m playing. I think it’s probably something that I’m drawn to tonally across the sexuality of the characters that I play.”
Hermanus said his approach to casting roles has always been tied to the connection that he builds with an actor and their talent, rather than their personal identity.

“As a filmmaker, I would hate it if somebody only offered me queer-based work because I’m a queer person,” he said. “I want the freedom to be able to tell stories in any way I can within reason of representation. So I think any artist wants the freedom to interpret, and I don’t like the idea of being denied in that way.”

O’Connor said when he’s approaching any role, the starting point is like, “‘What can I draw from my own life into these characters?’ And sometimes, there are aspects of a character that are a stretch, and sometimes there’s not.” He added that there’s so much in the character of David that resonated with him.

“I really remember reading that short story the first time. It hit me so hard. The duality of fear, love, grief, and the sort of optimism with a sort of undercurrent of sadness — that would just rip my heart out,” he said. “So I just think we are so fortunate to get to play diverse roles in our career.”

title: 'Mormon Wives' Star Taylor Frankie Paul Is the Next 'Bachelorette'
summary: "The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives" star Taylor Frankie Paul is the next Bachelorette. Who is she? What to know about her kids, controversies and history.
story: "The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives" star Taylor Frankie Paul is the next Bachelorette.

The news was announced on the Sept. 10 episode of the "Call Her Daddy" podcast. During the episode, "Call Her Daddy" host Alex Cooper asked Paul how it felt to be the next person on the hit show looking for love.

This story is breaking. Please check back shortly for more.

title: Rosie O’Donnell Calls This Remark By Ellen DeGeneres ‘One of The Most Painful Things' to Ever Happen to Her
summary: Rosie O’Donnell is recalling what led to the current strained relationship between her and Ellen DeGeneres.
story: Rosie O’Donnell is recalling what led to the current strained relationship between her and Ellen DeGeneres.

During an appearance on the “No Filter” podcast hosted by Kate Langbroek, O’Donnell opened up about why the two comics and former talk show hosts had a falling out over 20 years ago. In the episode, which was released Sept. 8, Langbroek asked O’Donnell about the major cultural moment in 1997 when DeGeneres, and her character, came out during “The Puppy Episode” of her sitcom “Ellen.”
O’Donnell shared that it felt “very threatening” watching that episode as a person who hadn’t publicly confirmed their sexuality, before touching on her past friendship with DeGeneres.

“Everyone then wanted to know, ‘Well, are you gay?’” she said. At the time of “Ellen”’s peak, O’Donnell was also hosting her popular “The Rosie O’Donnell Show” daytime television show. Despite feeling threatened, she said she wanted DeGeneres to come on her show and talk about the groundbreaking sitcom.
“She came on my show, and I felt strongly that I didn’t want to leave her out there alone,” O’Donnell explained. “That I could not (as a) gay person act as though I was not the same as her.”

She said the two chatted about the sit-down backstage before the interview began. DeGeneres joked to O’Donnell that her “Ellen” character was going to “become Lebanese.” During the interview, after DeGeneres made the quip, O’Donnell responded by saying she could also be “Lebanese” because she was a fan of Casey Kasem.

“Everyone who was gay at home got it. Because I wouldn’t leave her out there alone. I couldn’t do it. So we had this, you know, really sort of decoded, coded, interaction that anyone who was gay knew. But, you know, the public didn’t really pick up on it,” O’Donnell said.

She continued, “It just felt like, ‘Oh, this could really threaten me.’ But still, my internal clock wouldn’t allow me to distance myself from her. I had to stand by her and hold her hand, and that’s what I chose to do. Then, you know, it’s funny, because she never really, I didn’t think, appreciated that moment.”
O’Donnell then shared the moment their friendship unraveled.

She remembered watching Larry King interview DeGeneres one night with her ex-wife Kelli Carpenter by her side. Larry asked DeGeneres about the ending of “The Rosie O’Donnell Show,” which aired its final episode in 2002. According to O’Donnell, she was offered to return to host the talk show, but she walked away because she wanted to focus on her family.

“He asked her, ‘Whatever happened to Rosie O’Donnell? Her show went down the tubes,’” O’Donnell said while mimicking the late broadcaster’s voice. “And Ellen said, ‘I don’t know Rosie. We’re not friends.’”
O’Donnell added, “That was like one of the most painful things that ever happened to me in show business in my life.”
She said she was stunned by DeGeneres’ reply given that the two had known each other for decades.

“I have photos of her holding my newborn babies. I knew her for 30 years,” she shared. O’Donnell said she was so upset at the time that she made t-shirts for her talk show staff that included the quote.
“It was very painful and, you know, we’ve never sort of gotten over it,” she told Langbroek.
TODAY.com has reached out to DeGeneres for a comment.

O’Donnell claimed DeGeneres never addressed the moment with her. She also pointed out that when “The Ellen DeGeneres Show” launched in 2003 it included some of the same production team members from “The Rosie O’Donnell Show.” But she said she didn’t “blame” DeGeneres for hiring the same people.

“But I did think that she was all of a sudden in the position I was in, where she was starting a show and wanted it to be successful and get the money and the accolades that came with it,” O’Donnell explained. “And instead of deciding to stand next to me and hold my hand, which is what I did to her, she did the opposite. I couldn’t believe it.”
She emphasized repeatedly that she and DeGeneres are not similar people.
O’Donnell previously spoke about DeGeneres when the former talk show host faced toxic workplace allegations in 2020.

“You can’t fake your essence,” O’Donnell replied when asked about the claims on Busy Philipps’ podcast at the time. “That’s why I have compassion for Ellen, right? I have compassion, even though, you know, I hear the stories and I understand. I think she has some social awkwardness.”

title: What Happened With Ayo Edebiri, Julia Roberts, Andrew Garfield and an Italian Journalist?
summary: An Italian journalist's interview with “After the Hunt” stars Ayo Edebiri, Julia Roberts and Andrew Garfield has prompted backlash. Here's what happened.
story: An Italian journalist, who drew widespread attention for her interview with “After the Hunt” stars Ayo Edebiri, Julia Roberts and Andrew Garfield, has finally addressed the controversial moment.

Following an interview for Italy's ArtsLife posted on Sept 5, journalist Federica Polidoro faced backlash after seemingly excluding Edebiri from a conversation around the #MeToo and Black Lives Matter movements in Hollywood.

During the interview, Polidoro called the movements “done” and solely asked Roberts and Garfield their thoughts on the future of political efforts in the entertainment industry. After appearing shocked at seemingly being ignored, Edebiri immediately piped in to answer the question.

While the interaction prompted controversy, Polidoro defended her question in a statement she shared to Instagram on Sept. 8, adding that she’s been “subjected to personal insults and attacks” following the virality of the interview.
So what exactly happened in the interview? Read on for a detailed breakdown, as well as Polidoro's full response.
What Happened During the Interview?
For Italy’s ArtsLife, Polidoro interviewed “After the Hunt” stars Edebiri, Roberts and Garfield about their upcoming film from Italian director Luca Guadagnino.

At one point, Polidoro asked, in part, what can be expected in Hollywood now that “the MeToo movement and Black Live Matters are done.” After asking the question, all three actors looked at one another for a moment before the journalist clarified she wanted “the two of you, Andrew and Julia” to answer.
“Oh! OK,” Edebiri responded with a slight laugh, before Roberts leaned over and asked Polidoro to repeat the question.
“With your sunglasses on, I can’t tell which of us you’re talking to, so,” Roberts said.

Reiterating the phrasing of her question, Polidoro said, “The question was for Julia and Andrew. Now that the MeToo era and Black Lives Matters are done, what do you expect in Hollywood? And what (did we lose) — if we lost something — in the political er?”
While Polidoro repeated her question, Edebiri was seen looking surprised and glancing off screen, then letting out a shocked smile while shaking her head.
Almost immediately after the question was asked, Roberts said, “It’s not done,” while Edebiri simultaneously began responding.

“Well, sorry, yeah, I know that that’s not for me — and I don’t know if it’s purposeful that it’s not for me — but I just, I’m curious,” Edebiri began. “I don’t think it’s done. I don’t think it’s done at all.”

“Maybe hashtags might not be used as much or, but I do think there’s work being done by activists, by people every day that’s beautiful, important work that’s not finished that’s really, really, really active for a reason because this world is really charged,” she continued.
As Edebiri spoke, her co-stars continuously made supportive remarks, with Roberts saying, “I agree with you, it’s not done” of the movements.
“The Bear” star added that while the #MeToo and Black Lives Matter movements may currently receive less “mainstream coverage” than in the past, “I don’t think that it means that the work is done.”

“And the movements haven’t been halted in any way. The movements are absolutely alive, as you say,” Andrews said, addressing Edebiri. “Just maybe not as labeled or covered or witnessed or magnified as much in this present moment.”
What Has Italian Journalist Federica Polidoro Said About the Interview?
After the interview sparked controversy and backlash, Polidoro broke her silence Sept. 8 in a lengthy statement on Instagram, defending the phrasing of her question.

As an Instagram reel and in the complimentary caption, Polidoro wrote that she has been “subjected to personal insults and attacks because of a question that,” adding that “for some reason,” the question “was not well received by some members of the public.”

“I find it striking that those who unjustly accuse me of racism and consider themselves custodians of justice find acceptable violent language, personal attacks, and cyberbullying,” she wrote. “I would like to clarify that, rather than focusing on the thoughtful responses of Ayo Edebiri, Julia Roberts, and Andrew Garfield, the discussion continues solely on how I should have phrased the question.”

“All the contributions from those present were reported in full in the published interview, without any omissions,” she continued. “To date, I am not aware of any protocol that dictates the order in which questions must be asked in an interview.”

Addressing the online backlash, Polidoro wrote that solely the Journalists’ Association has the power to “evaluate the work of professionals,” adding that “censoring or delegitimizing questions considered ‘uncomfortable’ does not fall within the practice of democracy.”

"To those who unjustly accuse me of racism, I would like to clarify that in my work I have interviewed people of every background and ethnicity, and my own family is multi-ethnic, matriarchal, and feminist, with a significant history of immigration," she wrote.

Polidoro claimed to have worked with “numerous national and international publications of all political orientations” for over 20 years, while “always approaching my work with openness and professional rigor.”
“In my view, the real racists are those who see racism everywhere and seek to muzzle journalism, limiting freedom of analysis, critical thinking, and the plurality of perspectives,” she added.
Concluding her statement, Polidoro maintained that her role as a journalist is to “ask questions, even on delicate topics, with respect and responsibility.”

“I will not tolerate or accept defamatory or violent language, and I reserve the right to seek legal protection against those who, in recent days, have chosen to hide behind the digital mob to insult and attack me instead of seeking a civil and constructive discussion,” Polidoro wrote.

title: Apple Martin Launches Modeling Career With a Series of Selfies
summary: Apple Martin, the 21-year-old daughter of Gwyneth Paltrow and Chris Martin, stars in her first fashion campaign with Self-Portrait, sharing playful selfies to mark the debut.
story: Apple Martin is in her model era.

She has landed her first major brand deal as the new face of London fashion house Self-Portrait. The modern fashion house and the 21-year-old college student, who is the daughter of Chris Martin and Gwyneth Paltrow, announced their collaboration with a series of cheeky Instagram posts Sept. 9.
“It is me, Ms. Apple Blythe Alison Martin, coming to you from the floor in a gorge Self-Portrait lil baby tee and these cute a– earrings,” she said in a clip before flashing a wide grin.
She added, “I’m so excited to be the new Miss Self-Portrait and for the campaign to come out!”
The second post included two photos of Martin taking selfies while wearing a red and white T-shirt and matching red shorts.
“Welcome to the family @applemartin,” the fashion house captioned the snaps.
For her final post, Martin and the brand shared a selfie of her posing in a white halter top.
Fans filled the comments with messages to Martin, whose personal Instagram account is private, congratulating her about leading her first fashion campaign.

Self-Portrait, which was founded in the UK in 2013 by designer Han Chong, explained in a press release that the intent of the announcement was to show “the effortless, confident and self-expressive spirit of a generation of young customers that continues to inspire the fashion house and its designs.”
The British brand revealed that more fashion portraits, films and activations with Martin will arrive in the coming months.
Martin follows other famous faces who have partnered with the brand, including Emily Ratajkowski, Gigi Hadid, Naomi Campbell, Bella Hadid and Kate Moss.

Martin’s team-up with Self-Portrait marks her official step into the spotlight. She has opened up in the past about attempting to keep her life out of the public eye in interviews. In April, she spoke with Interview magazine about growing up with two famous parents and navigating fame.

“It’s interesting because I grew up with that uneven balance of getting out of the airport with my mom and being bombarded with cameras, and then just being a normal kid,” she told editor-in-chief Mel Ottenberg at the time.

Martin, a student at Vanderbilt University, continued, “I remember I read ‘Discipline and Punish’ (by Michel Foucault), which is a great book, but talking about the surveillance state — I feel like I’ve grown up with that, which is really scary and makes me very anxious about making mistakes.”
She said she previously attempted to ignore any headlines that mentioned her, but she later learned to feel less pressure in the spotlight.

“I’m getting a lot better at being like, ‘F— it.’ I’m not going to be scared. I just want to do what seems fun and figure my life out,” said Martin, who also shared she was interested in becoming a lawyer.

title: Darius Rucker Introduces His 'Love' Five Years After Split From His Wife
summary: Darius Rucker is going Instagram official with his girlfriend, songwriter and social media personality Emily Deahl
story: Darius Rucker is going Instagram official with his girlfriend, songwriter and social media personality Emily Deahl.
The 59-year-old musician shared a selfie Sept. 8 on Instagram that showed the couple posing together in front of the Sphere arena in Las Vegas.
"Wizard of Oz at @spherevegas with my love & my boys. 1000/10!!!!!" he captioned the post.

Rucker's post comes two days after Deahl shared a humorous selfie video on Instagram. "Waking up in the US after living abroad for a year," she wrote on her video. She captioned her post "London Calling."
Deahl has been mentioning her move from Nashville to London in videos on both YouTube and TikTok since at least February 2025.
Meanwhile, Rucker confirmed in February on Instagram that he, too, had been "living in London" while working on music and performing live.
According to Deahl's official website, she grew up in Rucker's home state of South Carolina and is inspired by the music of Jack White, Lady Gaga, Freddie Mercury and Elvis Presley.
Rucker’s update about his new romance comes more than five years after he and his ex-wife, Beth Leonard, announced they were splitting after 20 years of marriage.

“Beth and I would like to share that after much reflection we have made the decision to consciously uncouple,” Ruckus wrote on Instagram, using a phrase popularized by Gwyneth Paltrow and Chris Martin when they divorced. “We remain close friends and parenting partners and continue to be each other’s biggest cheerleaders.”

“Our priority will always be our beautiful family,” he continued. “We have so much love in our hearts for each other and will continue to encourage growth and expansion in one other. Please be kind as we take on this journey, and we thank you for your love and support always.”
Rucker and Leonard met when Leonard was working for VH1 in New York and Rucker traveled to the city to perform with his band Hootie & the Blowfish, according to Wide Open Country.
They tied the knot in 2000, according to People, and welcomed two children: daughter Daniella and son Jack. Rucker is also a dad to a daughter named Caroline from a previous relationship.

title: Hilary Duff Is Set to Make a Music Comeback. Here Are the Details
summary: Hilary Duff has announced she's signed a record deal with Atlantic Records and has a docuseries in the works about her music comeback.
story: Hilary Duff is making a surprise return to music — and her fans couldn't be happier.
The 37-year-old singer and actor, who hasn't released an album of new songs since 2015's “Breathe In. Breathe Out.,” has signed a deal with Atlantic Records, according to a Sept. 9 press release.

The former “Lizzie McGuire” and “Younger” star is also collaborating with Sam Wrench, the filmmaker behind “Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour” and “A Nonsense Christmas with Sabrina Carpenter,” on an "intimate docuseries" that chronicles her return to music and her personal journey, the release said.

The docuseries will embrace "the ups, downs, and everything in between" and show Duff "as she balances raising a family, recording new music, live show rehearsals, and preparing to perform on stage for the first time in over a decade."
Duff also shared the news, albeit with fewer details, the same day on Instagram.

"New music … or something," she captioned a trio of photos on Instagram. One pic showed Duff wearing jeans and a T-shirt as she lounged in a chair next to a drum. Another showed her embracing her musician husband, Matthew Koma, as he played a keyboard in what looked to be a recording studio.
Another pic showed Duff's hands holding a smartphone next to a pair of headphones.

Koma, who collaborated with Duff on her last studio album, shared the same photos in his Instagram stories along with the image of a Billboard news article about Duff's new projects, over which he wrote, "Let's. F------. Go."
Fans hopped into the comments of Duff's post to express their excitement over the news.
"This is what dreams are made of," several wrote in honor of Duff's 2003 song "What Dreams Are Made Of."
"So happy to hear you're coming out with music again soon! I feel like doing cartwheels," wrote another.
"I’M CRYING TEARS OF JOY," added a third.
Duff shot to stardom in 2001 as the star of the Disney Channel tween sitcom "Lizzie McGuire," which led to 2003's "The Lizzie McGuire Movie."
She went on to star in several more TV shows and movies, including the long-running "Younger" and Hulu’s "How I Met Your Mother" spinoff "How I Met Your Father."
Along the way, Duff released five studio albums, including 2003's "Metamorphosis," which included the Billboard Hot 100 hits “So Yesterday" and “Come Clean."
She scored additional hits later with the singles “Wake Up” and “With Love."

title: See the ‘Love Island Games’ Season 2 Cast
summary: Who is in the cast of Love Island Games Season 2? Read on for a list and their bios, as well as where you know them from.
story: Nearly two years after the "Love Island Games" first debuted, the “Love Island” spinoff is returning for its second season.

On Sept. 9, Peacock revealed the 14 Islanders who make up the initial cast of “Love Island Games” Season 2, featuring fan-favorites from iterations of “Love Island” from different countries. The streamer also announced how it is shaking up the format of the competition series for its sophomore season.

For Season 2, which will be hosted by Ariana Madix, the action will unfold in real time, similar to the original show. In comparison, Season 1 was recorded months prior to the release date and ended with Justine Ndiba and Jack Fowler being crowned the winners.
The change means that viewers will now be able to vote for their favorite couples using the Love Island USA app, impacting which Islanders couple up together and who will be sent home.

In case you aren’t familiar, “Love Island Games” takes place at the same Fijian villa seen in “Love Island USA.” There, unforgettable Islanders from various “Love Island” series partner up and compete in a series of challenges. They’ll also face eliminations, unexpected arrivals and twists while forming connections and, possibly, finding love.
“‘Love Island Games’ is craaaazzzyyy,” as “Love Island USA” Season 5 star Kay Kay Gray puts it in the introduction video for the Season 2 cast.

Season 2 will arrive on Tuesday, Sept. 16, with a two-hour premiere on Peacock. New episodes will be released every day at 6 p.m. PT/ 9 p.m. ET during premiere week. Then, the following week and the rest of the season new episodes will stream Thursdays through Tuesdays.

Comedian Iain Stirling will return as the narrator, Cely Vazquez will continue to serve as social ambassador and Maura Higgins will resume her role as the host of the weekly “Love Island Aftersun” recap show. The recap, which airs Saturdays, will include surprise guests.

So, who is joining Kay Kay in the villa? Read on to get to know the cast of “Love Island Games” Season 2, including where you’ve seen them before in the “Love Island” franchise and what you can expect from their return to reality television.
Meet the Cast of ‘Love Island Games’ Season 2

Peacock has announced the first round of islanders who will enter the villa for “Love Island Games” Season 2. The singles come from versions of “Love Island” across the globe, including the original UK show, USA, France, Malta, Belgium and the Netherlands. Just like the flashship series, more islanders will make their way into the villa as the season progresses.
The 14 islanders who are kicking off Season 2 of “Love Island Games” are…
Andrea Carmona
Where you’ve seen her before: “Love Island USA” Season 6
“Last season, I kind of got robbed, pun intended. When that whole thing happened, I was just hurt. But it’s only up from here for me.”

Where you’ve seen her before: “Love Island USA” Season 7
“Guess who’s back? Now I know what to do, baby. I know I can’t put my eggs in one basket. I’m ready to play the game. But also, I just want to be loved.”
Charlie Georgio
Where you’ve seen him before: “Love Island USA” Season 7
Charlie didn’t appear in the teaser, suggesting that he might be the first male bombshell of the season. It is a role he is used to as the Brit entered the villa on day two in Season 7.

Where you’ve seen him before: “Love Island USA” Season 7
“May the best man win — me. I’m the man. I don’t give a f--- about stepping on toes. I’m stepping on whatever.”

“I am not a very sporty person, so you don’t see me coming. I’m an underdog, but I’m going to come for you.”

Where you’ve seen him before: “Love Island USA” Season 4
“I’m here for love. The only thing I’m nervous about is the challenges. But we’re going to do it! In a speedo! “

“I got the brains. I got the looks. I got the banter, as they say. It’s game day, baby. Let’s go!”

“Hand me my crown. Obviously, I would love to win this. But just the thought that I could find something real and authentic gives me a little bit of goose bumps.”

title: Julianne Moore Has Cheeky Response to Her Bob Haircut Making Headlines
summary: Julianne Moore debuted her bob haircut cut earlier this year, and is now reacting to the viral response that has come from it.
story: Julianne Moore debuted her bob cut earlier this year, and is now looking back on the positive buzz it caused.
While appearing on TODAY with Jenna & Friends on Sept. 9, Jenna Bush Hager pointed out Moore's shorter hairstyle, which she switched up in the spring.
"You recently got a haircut," Jenna said.
"I did. You got a haircut too, I see," the "Sirens" actor replied, referring to Jenna's own bob, which she revealed on the show in June.
Jenna went on to note that Moore's haircut "made headlines," much like hers did.
"Thank God. I mean, honestly, why cut your hair if you're not gonna be noticed in the press?" Moore joked.
Jenna, who shared over the summer that she plans to keep her shorter hair for the time being, was curious to know if Moore has had fun with her new haircut.

"Yeah, but you know, I can't do it myself. That's really what it comes down to, so I don't know how long I'm going to be able to maintain it because I cannot blow dry my own hair. That's a life skill that I don't possess," Moore said.
Nikki Glaser, who was guest co-hosting alongside Jenna, said she thought having shorter hair would be "easier to style," but that that doesn't appear to be the case.
“Not if your hair goes into an A-line naturally,” Moore said.
While attending the premiere for her Netflix series "Sirens" in May, Moore turned heads on the red carpet with her shorter hairstyle.
For the event, the 64-year-old sported her bob in a bouncy blowout with plenty of shine. She paired the hairstyle with a black spaghetti strap dress with ruffles at the bust.
The following month, Moore attended the European premiere of “Echo Valley” and called attention to her shorter do with some drop earrings.

title: Cillian Murphy Finally Reacts to Being Mistaken for Zombie in '28 Years Later' Trailer
summary: Cillian Murphy finally shares his reaction to fans thinking that he was the zombie depicted in the trailer for "28 Years Later."
story: Cillian Murphy is aware that fans thought he was an emaciated zombie in the trailer for "28 Years Later," and he delivered the perfect response to it.

The "Oppenheimer" star reacted to previous speculation that a zombie featured in the trailer for this year's film "28 Years Later," the hit sequel to the original movie "28 Days Later," was actually Murphy in prosthetics as a member of the undead.

A split-second moment in the trailer shows a shirtless, bony zombie rising to its feet. Fans speculated that it was the undead version of his character, Jim, from the original film. Murphy's character did not appear in the 2007 sequel, "28 Weeks Later."

Murphy, 49, who is generally averse to being online, told The Observer in an interview published on Sept. 6 that one of his two sons showed him the zombie from the trailer that people thought was him.
“That’s great people think I look like a zombie cadaver,” he said in a dry manner. “It’s very flattering.”
The zombie in the trailer was actually played by model Angus Neill, according to a report by The Guardian.

The “28 Years Later” film released in June is the first part of a planned trilogy from Danny Boyle, who directed the original movie about Jim navigating a post-apocalyptic Britain. Jim is expected to return for the next movie, “28 Years Later: The Bone Temple,” which hits theaters in January 2026.

Murphy told The Observer he's only in the movie "for a little bit." However, he said that short appearance sets up a much larger role for the third installment of the trilogy, which has not been confirmed to be made yet.
“Everyone’s got to go and see the second one﻿,” he said. “I’m sure they will — it’s really, really good.”

The original film has become beloved by fans of horror, post-apocalyptic films and zombies. It also became a touch point during the COVID-19 pandemic, with its shots of Jim in deserted city streets and standing on London's empty Westminster Bridge.
"People still love that movie,” Murphy said. “It’s the same with 'Peaky (Blinders),' we didn’t realize it would become as beloved as it was.”

title: Naomi Watts Reflects On College Drop-Off Day for Son Sasha: 'Ugly Cried All the Way Home'
summary: Naomi Watts says she got emotional when she dropped her son, Sasha, off at college with his father and former partner, Liev Schreiber.
story: Naomi Watts had quite the experience when she dropped her 18-year-old son, Sasha, off at college with his father and her former partner, Liev Schreiber.

On the Sept. 9 episode of the 3rd Hour of TODAY, where the actor also raised awareness for menopause on National Hot Flash Day, Watts recalled what that day felt like and said she felt a mix of emotions.
"I feel really good because he was ready. He was prepared. He loves the school," she said.
"It was very successful, but lots of tears, too — ugly cried all the way home," she added.
Sasha is currently attending school at the University of Southern California. On Aug. 20, Watts shared a bunch of photos online of her and Schreiber dropping their older kid off at school.

The two are also proud parents to their 16-year-old daughter, Kai, and Schreiber is also a father to his 2-year-old daughter, Hazel, whom he shares with his wife, Taylor Neisen. Watts is married to actor Billy Crudup.
In one of the snaps, Sasha was seen posing next to his parents in what appears to be his new dorm room, and in another pic, he smiled while standing next to a group of young men in a kitchen.
In the caption, Watts recalled how busy their day was and said she's happy that Sasha is starting a new chapter in his life.

"We packed and unpacked, stacked and color coded. We walked and walked, woke up early with excitement. Then we shopped and shopped, and sometimes fought about stupid stuff," she wrote. "We laughed, we cried, I had a few extra secret cries and maybe some not so private ones."

"We hugged a lot. We built things, we talked to robots, we ate good food. We got lost a bunch. We met so many great people. We had deep talks mixed in with a few fart jokes... 🤣 then gave advice about how the world works," she added.
At the end of the caption, Watts said she's proud of the person Sasha is becoming.
"He’s got this!! He did it!! He dreamed big and worked really hard for something wonderful. Go @sashapeteschreiber — we love you so much."

title: Jay Leno Opens Up About Life With Wife Mavis Amid Dementia Diagnosis
summary: Jay Leno opens up about life with his wife, Mavis, amid her dementia diagnosis, revealing why he finds purpose in being her caretaker.
story: Jay Leno says being a caregiver for his wife of 45 years, Mavis Leno, following her diagnosis of advanced dementia gives him "purpose."

“My wife’s got some problems, so it’s just her and I. But it’s always been her and I for the last 45 years anyway, so it’s fine. I enjoy taking care of her. It’s fun,” the former "Tonight Show" host, 75, recently told People.

“People think, ‘Oh, it must be horrible.’ No, because she’s not in any pain. She’s not suffering,” he continued of Mavis Leno, 79. “It’s not like a tumor or cancer. It’s just a confusion that comes with Alzheimer’s and dementia. And that’s okay.”
“I enjoy being her rock. It makes you feel wanted. You got a purpose now. So it’s good," he added.
Jay Leno added that despite her dementia struggles, his wife still gets fired up when it comes to women's issues.

He described how Mavis Leno recently became angry while watching an episode of the throwback cop show “Hawaii Five-O.” The episode centered around a genetic scientist whose adult daughter told police of his work, ‘Well, I’m just a woman. I don’t understand such things.’”
“My wife was real involved with women’s issues,” said Jay Leno, who jokingly imitated how his wife heard the line and growled.
"She’s just yelling at the TV. She still got the fire. It just made me laugh,” he said.
In April 2024, Jay Leno was granted conservatorship over his wife's estate following her diagnosis of advanced dementia.
His update about the couple's life at home comes more than four months after he discussed his caretaking role during an April 23 interview on “In Depth with Graham Bensinger'.”

“I enjoy the time with my wife. If I go home, I cook dinner for her, watch TV, and it’s OK. It’s basically what we did before, except now I have to feed her and do all those things,” he explained. “But, I like it. I like taking care of her. She’s a very independent woman, so I like that I’m needed.”
Jay Leno also described how he uses flashcards to help his wife remember their life together, and even manages to infuse their sessions together with laughs.

“I’m told people with dementia forget the people they’re with. But, you know, I do pictures of the flashcards,” he said, pretending to place a card down and saying, “‘Remember? Remember?’ It’s kind of funny. I go, ‘Honey, that’s President Obama. Remember we had dinner?’”
"'Oh, not me,'" he said his wife would respond. “‘Yeah, yeah. Honey, it was you’ … You have to find the humor in it.”
Helping his wife in this way, he added, is "what defines a marriage."

"I mean, that’s really what love is. That’s what you do. I mean, I’m glad I didn’t cut and run," shared Jay Leno. "I’m glad I didn’t run off with some woman half my age or any of that silly nonsense. I would rather be with her than doing something else.”
He has faced his own health issues in recent years.

In November 2024, the comedian sustained minor injuries after falling down a hill and hitting “a bunch of rocks," he told Inside Edition. “I broke my wrist. And then I’m all black and blue from 60 feet of hitting rocks,” he said at the time.
In 2023, Jay Leno sustained a broken collarbone, two broken ribs and two cracked kneecaps in a motorcycle accident.
The previous year, he was severely burned in a garage fire while working on one of his collectible cars.

title: Malin Åkerman Reveals the 1 'Hunting Wives' Scene She Sobbed Over After Filming
summary: Malin Åkerman tells TODAY.com the Margo and Jed slap scene in "The Hunting Wives" was "really hard" for her and Dermot Mulroney to film.
story: While “The Hunting Wives” is filled with fun, campy moments, at its core there is a lot of darkness, mostly centered around the murder of a teenager named Abby.
One dark scene in particular was “really hard” for two of its stars, according to Malin Åkerman.
“Once we were done with the scene, I ended up just sobbing,” she tells TODAY.com.

In the show, Åkerman plays east Texas royalty, Margo Banks, who is in a flexible marriage with businessman and politician Jed Banks (Dermot Mulroney). Jed and Margo allow each other to sleep with partners outside of their relationship, as long as they are women. Margo breaks one of their rules when she starts a relationship with one of her friends’ sons, Brad, who is just 18.

Jed and Margo had struggled to conceive, but with Brad she gets pregnant and has an abortion. She confesses this to Jed in a tense scene near the end of the season, after another one of Margo’s lovers, Sophie O’Neil (Brittany Snow), realizes Margo is Abby’s killer.
After telling Jed she slept with Brad and had an abortion that Abby, who was also Brad's girlfriend, found out about, Jed slaps Margo.
“I don’t want to hear another f------ word — about any of it,” he says before kicking her out of their house.
Åkerman says the scene was harder on Mulroney, whom she says is one of her “favorite humans.”
“He did not like that at all,” she says, describing the whole experience making the scene as “just a lot.”
“When you really get into that, and you have a man slap you, it’s a weird feeling,” Åkerman continues, noting that her husband, Jack Donnelly, also did not like it.

“He’s like, ‘I loved the whole show. I hated that scene. I wanted to kill Dermot.’ And he knows Dermot and loves him, but it was just — it’s so visceral. And there’s so much in it. So that was a tough day,” she says.
The show’s creator and executive producer, Rebecca Cutter, previously told TODAY.com she loved the scene and is happy to brag on both Åkerman's and Mulroney’s performances.
“The second I saw it in the very first cut, I was like, ‘That f------ hits. Like, that just works.’ That scene is electric,” Cutter said.
While Cutter acknowledged the pregnancy admission is partially responsible for Jed’s outburst, she added, “I also think she was inching towards confessing about Abby.”
Åkerman estimates they did the scene in two or three takes.

“It was very minimal,” she says, “and Dermot was so lovely. After, he was like, ‘I don’t know if I should approach her or not.’ He told my makeup artist … ‘Check if she’s OK. Somebody hold her.’ Because he didn’t know if he should or — and then we hugged it out after.”
“You just bring yourself into it, and you dig deep,” she explains. “So, it was not my favorite thing.”
She was, however, thrilled to be paired with Mulroney on the series, an adaptation of May Cobb’s novel.
“Dermot is incredible. He’s the heartthrob from ‘My Best Friend’s Wedding,’ and it was just amazing to have him be my husband,” she says.

As for whether or not Margo and Jed will reconcile in a potential second season, Cutter said, “I think they’ll definitely have scenes together. … They’re both people that are sort of transactional in terms of like, ‘What can you do for me?’ I definitely think there’s a world where they benefit each other, and so they would make that work. And they’re attracted to each other.”

Margo hustled her way into Jed’s life after a rough upbringing. Her father had an affair with her mother, and Margo grew up essentially having to raise herself and her brother, Kyle. She managed to woo Jed out of his marriage to his previous wife after having a threesome with them.
Despite it all, Åkerman says she has sympathy for her character.

“She had to become a survivor in her life, and, you know, the thing is that we all have choices, and she’s made some bad ones,” she says. “So as a grown-up, you’ve got to take care of your stuff in order to move forward with your life. And I think she’s kind of just pushed a lot down and suppressed many, many things that maybe she needs a good therapist.”
“I think she’s incredible to be such a strong survivor,” she adds, “but I don’t agree with all her choices.”
Åkerman also says she was lucky to get the scripts for all eight episodes in advance to read Margo’s full arc.

“She’s an incredibly complicated, nuanced human, and for an actress, it’s so much fun to play that,” she says. “When you have a really four-dimensional character with lots of layers — she’s manipulative and sexy and fun and scary — I mean, it’s everything in one character.
“It’s juicy, and I was excited to jump in.”

title: Who Is Becca Bloom? All About the 'Queen of #RichTok' and Her Lavish Wedding
summary: Who is Rebecca Ma, better known as Becca Bloom? What to know about the influencer, her parents, her wedding to David Pownall and what she does for work.
story: Rebecca Ma, better known as Becca Bloom to her millions of social media followers, is the "queen of #RichTok" — and she just had a royal wedding of her own.

Since starting a TikTok in January of 2025, the 27-year-old has risen to fame — with over 6 million followers across platforms — for sharing her lavish lifestyle and her days as a working tech professional.
She garnered even more eyes for content related to her lavish Italian wedding, which was held in late August.
Here's a look into Ma's rapid rise to stardom and her buzzy nuptials.
Becca Bloom Has Been a Businesswoman Since High School

Raised in California by two business-savvy parents, Ma started three businesses in high school, according to a 2020 interview she did with LaunchX, an entrepreneurship program for high school students.
Ma detailed the businesses she co-founded, including Studipal, a peer-to-peer tutoring platform, and Hearth Wireless Chargers, a portable charging company.

At her high school, Menlo School in Atherton, Ma told the Wall Street Journal there was a focus on STEM education, noting that boys were pushed more into the field than girls. Ma said she "forced" herself to improve her math skills in order to compete.
She Now Works in Fintech

After taking the first semester of college off to focus on her existing business ventures, she attended the University of Southern California's Marshall School of Business, she said in the LaunchX interview.
Ma studied business and economics as an undergraduate, according to an August 2025 Wall Street Journal interview.
Ma told the Wall Street Journal that she has worked for “a pretty traditional finance technology firm” in a “client-facing” role since graduating, declining to name the company.
Becca Bloom's Parents Founded a Tech Company
Ma's parents, Simon Yiming Ma and Heidi Chou, met while working at working at IBM in California's Silicon Valley, she told the Wall Street Journal.
The two co-founded China-based technology company Camelot Information Systems.

In 2010, Camelot Information Systems went public, listed on the New York Stock Exchange, before going private in 2014, according to the documents from the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. According to a 2013 SEC filing, the equity value of Camelot was $98.2 million.
Ma told the Wall Street Journal that she “saw my parents working very hard, and that really inspired me.” She also said their focus is now on real estate.
In an Instagram post, Ma wrote that her parents have been “happily married for over 35 years.”
How Becca Bloom Became a TikTok Star

Ma started her TikTok account in January 2025. By April, she was a sensation. She signed with United Talent Agency that month, the agency representing fellow influencers like Alex Cooper, Alix Earle, Emma Chamberlain and Charli D’Amelio, among others.

While she told the Wall Street Journal the announcement has prompted brand deal opportunities, Ma maintained that she wants to continue working in finance. She currently posts almost no sponsored content.

On her TikTok page, Ma features videos showcasing her jet-setting lifestyle, dripping in designer clothes and accessories, as a businesswoman and socialite. But she also breaks down relationship and financial advice.
“I just want to show people that I’m multifaceted. I can talk about shopping and also finance and dating,” she told the Wall Street Journal.
Adding a disclaimer on her videos that she “doesn’t know anything about anything,” Ma told the publication that she hopes to bring her financial knowledge to a primarily female audience.
“My biggest pet peeve is men gatekeeping women from certain industries, especially STEM and finance,” Ma said, adding that she wants to “make that accessible to everybody.”
Despite noting to the Wall Street Journal that she is “not trying to tell anyone how to live,” Ma’s comment sections show her influence, with accounts saying they work to mimic her life.

In a March video walking followers through her “80-hour work week,” Ma showed that she wakes up around 5 a.m., works out by 5:30 a.m. before checking the markets. She then wrote that she spends hours in meetings and attending events with clients.
In the comments, one person wrote, “Being rich and still working is so admirable.”
Another wrote, “We love a hard working rich gworl.”
When another commenter wrote, “Do you ever get anxious at work and having to always take in the news,” Ma responded, “Im anxious 24/7” with a teddy bear and bandaged heart emoji.
“I’m not trying to be overly relatable, but I’m also not trying to be unrelatable,” she told the Wall Street Journal.
Becca Bloom Married David Pownall in Luxurious Wedding in Lake Como
On Aug. 28, Ma married Google software engineer David Pownall in an elaborate wedding on Lake Como, Italy.
In an interview with Vogue, Ma said they chose the day of their wedding because “a fortune teller told us this was the luckiest date.”
Ma told the publication that she and her now husband hosted their “intimate” 60-person wedding at Villa Balbiano.

“We’re both introverts — nerdy in the sense that we love numbers, puzzles, baking, and crafts together — and the thought of reading our vows in front of hundreds of people felt daunting," she told Vogue.

Ma noted, however, that her parents “always envisioned a grand celebration back home.” She said another celebration, a “spectacular, traditional Asian wedding on a much larger scale,” is still on the horizon.
Throughout their nearly two-year engagement, Ma described her bridal style as “very ‘type B,’” explaining that they approached wedding planning with as much ease and joy as possible.”
She Shared Details about the Wedding with Vogue
Ma broke down details about her outfits and beyond in her wedding profile with Vogue.

Rather than opting for a traditional all-white lineup, Ma donned more colorful looks. For the boat ride to the rehearsal dinner, she wore an Oscar de la Renta mini dress that resembled a pink-and-white flower, per Vogue. For the dinner itself, Ma wore a vintage Chanel high-low dress with an ice cream cone detail at the center.

“I know my wedding wardrobe choices were bolder and more colorful than the traditional white palette, but I wanted the weekend to feel playful and true to me,” she said. “I tried on countless white gowns, but in the end, I followed what made me happiest.”

For her wedding ceremony, Ma wore a custom Oscar de la Renta gown with embroidered peonies, “the unofficial flower of China,” she told Vogue. She paired the dress with white Chanel heels. Ma's jewelry was by Van Cleef & Arpels, a brand she often shows on social media.
Meanwhile, she said Pownall wore a Ralph Lauren Purple Label cream suit for the couple’s rehearsal dinner and Thom Browne for the ceremony.

In an Instagram post, Ma wrote that she walked down the aisle to “Can’t Help Falling in Love,” adding that Pownall was “already in tears at the altar before I even walked down the aisle.” Vogue reported that the couple recited vows they wrote themselves.

At the wedding reception, Ma donned another gown by Oscar de la Renta, a strapless pink dress that resembled shattered glass with rose details. Vogue reported that she paired the gown with a pair of Christian Louboutin ballet heels “as an ode to her years of dance.”
In an Instagram post, Ma recalled the sweet and amusing start to her first dance with Pownall, which Vogue reported was to Stephen Sanchez’s “Be More.”
“Hidden behind a curtain, David and I practiced our first dance and our secret handshake — starting off in the wrong direction, laughing until we found our rhythm,” she wrote.
In her post, which featured a compilation of playful dancing photos, Ma noted that she and her dad danced to “La Vie en Rose,” which he “once sang to me as a child.”
“At dinner, my mom presented me with a book she had written, David’s parents spoke through tears, and our friends toasted with stories that filled the room with love,” Ma’s post read, in part.
Vogue reported that dinner featured truffle pasta, paired with an Italian millefoglie "they’d built by hand" for dessert — as opposed to a traditional wedding cake.
Following the Italian fairytale nuptials, Ma told Vogue that she and Pownall are now looking to the future.

“What we’re most excited about is growing old together and having kids and maybe grandkids,” she said. “We play imaginary scenarios in our heads every single day and talk about, Oh, what if this happens? And, where would you want to retire?”
Becca Bloom Met Her Husband at a Coffee Shop
Ma told the Wall Street Journal that she and her future husband first wound up in conversation at Philz Coffee in Palo Alto in December 2019.

“I was home from college, and it was only David’s tenth day in the Bay Area after moving to the US from Vancouver,” she told the publication. “David asked if he could buy me a coffee, to which I responded, ‘I don’t drink coffee, only tea.’ Not exactly the flirtiest response, but somehow he rolled with it.”
Ma recalled the coffee turning into a day-long endeavor, saying she subsequently showed Pownall around the Palo Alto area, where she formerly lived. The two ended up at a sushi spot for dinner.
Becca Bloom and David Pownall Were Engaged in July 2023
About three and a half years after they met, Pownall proposed in July 2023 during a trip to Positano, Italy, Ma told the Wall Street Journal.
Recalling her engagement to the publication, Ma said Pownall unexpectedly popped the question on the first day of the trip during a private boat ride at sunset.
“He said it was for my ‘Instagram photoshoot,’ and I didn’t think twice about it,” she said.

Ma remembered Pownall showing up for the boat ride in a white linen shirt, while she opted for an orange Burberry bikini under a hot pink cover up with featured sleeves. After jokingly questioning her outfit choice, Pownall asked for a couple pic on the boat, Ma told the publication.
“I agreed, and that’s when he dropped to one knee and proposed,” she said. “From there, everything was a blur of joy.”
Ma shared the news shortly after in an Instagram post, showing off her engagement ring while seemingly on a boat. She captioned the photo carousel, “A lifetime of us” with a white heart emoji.

title: Lori Gottlieb and Gretchen Rubin Team up for New Advice Podcast ‘Since You Asked’
summary: New York Times bestselling authors Lori Gottlieb and Gretchen Rubin have teamed up for a new podcast advice series called "Since You Asked."
story: Lori Gottlieb and Gretchen Rubin have co-hosted their own hit podcasts. Now, they're teaming up for a new advice show, "Since You Asked."
In the weekly series, the longtime friends will assist listeners with their daily problems, from answering burning questions to providing tips you didn't know you needed.
An official trailer for the podcast shared exclusively with TODAY.com previews Gottlieb and Rubin discussing how they got the idea for their podcast.

“We were talking about how we have all these questions that we get asked, but we weren’t able to address all of them. And we thought, how great would it be to tackle them together? And so ‘Since You Asked’ was born,” Rubin said.
The podcast, a Lemonada Media original series, will officially drop Sept. 23.

“We all wrestle with life’s challenges, and sometimes the best thing we can do is ask for help," Gottlieb and Rubin said in a press release. "With ‘Since You Asked,’ we’re inviting listeners into a conversation that’s both practical and personal."
"We’re excited to share our expertise and our own stumbles and learn from our community along the way,” they added.

Rubin is a happiness expert, known for the hit 2009 book "The Happiness Project," while Gottlieb is a psychotherapist, a New York Times columnist and the author of "Maybe You Should Talk To Someone." They are also far from strangers to the podcasting world. Rubin co-hosts the "Happier with Gretchen Rubin” podcast alongside her sister Elizabeth Craft, while Gottlieb co-hosts "Dear Therapists."

The official trailer previews the kinds of questions Gottlieb and Rubin will tackle, including, "How do I do everything in my power to be a loving and supportive parent?" and "What is the best way to get my neighbor to put the dog on a leash?"
Listeners can send in their own dilemmas by leaving a message at the show's website, thesinceyouaskedpodcast.com
Jessica Cordova Kramer, CEO of Lemonada, expressed her excitement for the pair's new show in a press release.

"Lori and Gretchen are two of the most trusted voices when it comes to helping people live fuller, richer, more meaningful lives," Kramer said. "This new show brings their friendship, humor and wisdom together in a way that feels like sitting down with people who really get you."

title: 'Modern Family' Star Eric Stonestreet Marries Fiancée Lindsay Schweitzer on His Birthday
summary: "Modern Family" star Eric Stonestreet announced that he and his fiancée, Lindsay Schweitzer, married on his birthday in a post he shared on social media.
story: Eric Stonestreet and his fiancée, Lindsay Schweitzer, are married!
The "Modern Family" star and Schweitzer tied the knot for Stonestreet's 54th birthday. Stonestreet announced the happy news in a Sept. 9 Instagram post.
He wrote, "It’s my birthday and guess what I got."
TODAY.com has reached out to Stonestreet and Schweitzer for comment.
Stonestreet's post featured photos from his wedding day, including a beautiful black-and-white picture of him and his spouse kissing, and another pic of them posing for the camera together outside.
In one photo, he wrote "I GOT MARRIED!" and "The Stonestreets" on top of another.
For their nuptials, Stonestreet, who is known for playing Cameron in "Modern Family," donned a navy blue suit. As for Schweitzer, she wore a long, white silk dress.
"Of all second marriages, this one is my favorite!" Stonestreet's "Modern Family" co-star Jesse Tyler Ferguson commented on the post. "I love you both! I’m so happy for you!!!!"
Octavia Spencer said, "Congratulations! So happy for you both."
Michael Bublé commented with a string of heart emoji.
Stonestreet and Schweitzer got engaged in 2021. In their announcement, he shared a funny photo on Instagram of him pointing at Schweitzer's new engagement ring while she sat next to him.
In the caption, he joked, "She said, 'She’d have her people call my people.'"
During a December 2023 appearance on TODAY with Hoda & Jenna, Stonestreet talked about his engagement and revealed how he proposed to Schweitzer.

"I tricked her pretty good," he said. "I convinced her that a company was interested in us working together for an ad campaign. So we were doing a little test video, and I had the camera set up in front of her and then in the middle of it I just pulled out the ring."
Stonestreet also talked about their wedding and said he would like it to be in Kansas City. He is a native of Kansas City, Kansas.

"The idea is to build a house and host a wedding and do a reunion with all the 'Modern Family,'" he said. "I don't know how many times I can get all my my crew to Kansas City, so we want to do something special."

title: See a 20-Year-Old Kelly Clarkson on TODAY Days After Winning 'American Idol'
summary: Kelly Clarkson won "American Idol" 23 years ago. See her on TODAY in an interview.
story: Kelly Clarkson made history when she won the first season of "American Idol" in 2002.
The former waitress-turned-pop star beat fellow contestant Justin Guarini in the final on Sept. 4, with nearly 23 million watching from home.
Once she was named the winner of the fresh new competition series, Clarkson, then 20, immediately started crying because she knew her life was about to change forever — and change it did.
The Burleson, Texas native became an icon overnight. Once a regular girl, Clarkson was now a potential superstar with a burgeoning music career.
A few days after her win, Clarkson stopped by TODAY to process her new era.
In the interview with Katie Couric, Clarkson said her life after winning the series had been  a “whirlwind."
"I've done a little bit of everything, everything you could possibly think of," she said.
"Everything except sleep, right?" Couric replied.
"Yeah, I got about 45 minutes and I got a couple hours on the plane," Clarkson laughed tiredly.

Reflecting on her "American Idol" win, Clarkson said it was hard for her to perform "A Moment Like This" for the finale. The song was written specifically for the winner of the first season of "American Idol" to perform.
“I looked at my mom during that song, and I started bawling. I hated that,” she said.

Clarkson said her friends and family members had been supporting her throughout her journey. Even though Clarkson said she was too busy post-win to talk to anyone, she could feel their love in messages.
"They're ecstatic all over my voicemail," she said with a smile. "They're just so excited. Everybody's on my phone yelling. They're so supportive. I had the best time ever."
She also was humble about her win. "There are so many talented people out there. Who would've thunk it, walking in, out of 10,000 people? I never would have thought that," she said.

Clarkson said that she's already started mapping out her career. Along with securing a manager, she said she was getting ready to release two singles — “A Moment Like This” and “Before Your Love” — and also embark on the “American Idols Live! Tour," which featured the top 10 contestants from the first season.
“We’re really excited about the tour. All 10 of us are psyched,” she said.
"We have a bunch of stuff coming out," she added.
Couric wrapped the interview by congratulating Clarkson once again.
"Everybody's so happy for you, because you seem like such a nice person, and you're enormously talented, so we wish you a lot of success," Couric said.
Since that day, Clarkson has gone on to have a successful career within the music industry and beyond. She has released 10 studio albums and won three Grammy awards.
She's hosted "The Kelly Clarkson Show" since 2019 and has earned multiple Emmys in the process, including the Daytime Emmy Award for outstanding entertainment talk show host three years in a row.
Clarkson, now 43, has two children with her late ex-husband, Brandon Blackstock. Blackstock died of cancer earlier this year.
Clarkson looked back on the win in an Instagram post shared Sept. 4 of this year.

"To everyone that took time 23 years ago to call in and vote for me, thank you 🙏 Winning American Idol changed my life and I will be forever grateful for all of you that have supported me for so many years. It is a gift to find your purpose and passion, and to be able to make a living doing it is the cherry on top. Thank you, always," she wrote.

title: Where Is Lauryn Licari From Netflix's 'Unknown Number' Now?
summary: Where is Lauryn Licari from Unknown Number now? Documentarian Skye Borgman gives an update.
story: The Netflix documentary “Unknown Number: The High School Catfish" revisits the case of Kendra Licari, a Michigan mom who was convicted in 2023 of cyberbullying her teenage daughter, Lauryn Licari.

The harrowing documentary shows revisits how Lauryn Licari of Beal City, Michigan, and her then boyfriend began receiving cruel text messages from an unknown number first in October 2020, then in September 2021.

Over the course of more than a year, the taunting messages took on a more harassing tone. A group of parents, school officials, local police and later the FBI tried to uncover the identity of the mystery sender.
The documentary includes interviews with Lauryn Licari, who is now an adult, as well as her parents and law enforcement officials.
Lauryn Licari recalls in the film that she was getting “super frustrated” by the anonymous messages but her mother advised her to “just ignore them.”
“Like, she was just encouraging me to not read them,” she told filmmakers.
A 'Truly Horrible' Case
Beal City residents and officials were shocked when it turned out that Kendra Licari was the person sending her daughter and her boyfriend the texts.

In December 2022, the disgraced mom was charged with two counts of stalking a minor, two counts of communicating with another to commit a crime and one count of obstruction of justice, according to an Isabella County arrest warrant obtained by TODAY.com.
She pleaded guilty to two counts of stalking a minor in March 2023, and the other charges were dismissed, according to an Isabella County sentencing document obtained by TODAY.com
In April 2023, Kendra Licari was sentenced to a maximum of five years in prison, with a minimum sentence of one year and seven months, per the sentencing document.
At her sentencing, Judge Mark Duthie said the case had shown him the “worst in human nature,” according to courtroom reporting from The Morning Sun newspaper.
“I can’t imagine any parent saying such horrible things to her own daughter,” he added.
Kendra Licari was released from prison in 2024.
Where Is Lauryn Licari Now?
Lauryn Licari graduated from high school in 2025 and is “ready to enter ... the next phase of her life.” Skye Borgman, who directed "Unknown Number," previously told TODAY.com.
Though her mother has repeatedly expressed remorse about her crime, Lauryn Licari said in the documentary that it will be a challenge to trust her mother again.

“I think I want to trust her now, but I don’t think I can,” she said. “Now that she’s out, I just want her to get the help she needs so then when we see each other, it doesn’t go back to the old ways and how it was before.”
She also said she has plans to see her mom “when the time is right.”
“Being without that relationship I think is really hurting me, and I think rebuilding our relationship will help both of us a lot,” she told filmmakers. “I love her more than anything.”
Where Is Kendra Licari?
Kendra Licari was released on parole on Aug. 8, 2024. As a parolee, she will supervised until February 2026, according to her inmate record from the Michigan Department of Corrections.
As part of the conditions of her supervised release, she cannot leave the state of Michigan and must make “earnest efforts” to find and keep a job, according to her inmate record.
She also agreed in her plea deal to not see her daughter.
Kendra Licari said in “Unknown Number” that she believes she and her daughter can mend their relationship, telling filmmakers, “We both know that we’re with each other, no matter what."

title: Lady Gaga Pens Romantic Letter to Fiancé Michael Polansky After VMA Win
summary: A day after Lady Gaga gave her fiancé, Michael Polansky, a sweet shoutout at the 2025 MTV Video Music Awards, she wrote an emotional love letter to him.
story: A day after Lady Gaga gave her fiancé, Michael Polansky, a sweet shoutout at the 2025 MTV Video Music Awards, she let him know again how much he means to her in an emotional love letter.

The “Abracadabra” singer, 39, who performed at Madison Square Garden in New York City shortly after winning the artist of the year award at the VMAs Sunday night, posted two pics of her and Polansky to Instagram Sept. 8. In the caption, she wrote, "Dreaming up this album, making the plan, building every vision with you — talking endlessly about what we would create and do for monsters has been an experience I could not have ever imagined."

"I love how much you love my fans and want them to be happy," she continued, adding a black heart. "It fills my heart with happiness how much you love them because we get to love them every day together — you care as much as I do about people feeling seen in the world."
